title: Memorials of Edinburgh in the olden time
author: Wilson, Daniel
snippet: On the south side of the ancient Burgh of Broughton, and nearly on the site of the present broad street called Picardy Place, there existed till near the close of last century a small village or hamlet called Picardy, which was occupied exclusively by a body of weavers who are said to have been brought over from the French province of that name by the British Linen Company, and settled there for the improvement of their manufactures.1 We have found, however, in a copy of Lord Hades' Annals, a manuscript note, apparently written while this little community of foreign artizans were still industriously plying their looms, in which they are described as a body of French refugees, who fled to this country after the revocation of the Edict of Nantes, in 1685, and settling on the open common that then lay between Broughton and the old capital, they attempted to establish a silk manufactory. A large plantation of mulberry trees is said to have been laid out by them on the slope of Moutrie's Hill, and other provision made for carrying on the whole operations of the silk manufacture there.
